meaning: In Japanese, 伺 means “to ask; to visit”.
origin_text: You can see two men here.
One man is pointing at somewhere.
Because the other man asked:
Where is the bathroom?
So 伺 means “to ask”.
examples: 電でん話わ番号ばんごうを伺うかがえますか？
May I ask for your phone number?
私わたしが直ちょく接せつお伺うかがいします。
I’ll personally visit you.
一ひとつお伺うかがいしたいのですが。
I’d like to ask a question.
お名な前まえ伺うかがってよろしいですか？
May I ask your name?
明日あした伺うかがってもよろしいですか。
May I come and see you tomorrow?
ご意い見けんを伺うかがってもよろしいでしょうか。
Can I ask your opinion?

reading: Note: There is some difference between Chinese kanji and Japanese kanji, you should use Japanese kanji. (Which has 歯 on the left.)
origin_text: 齢 = 歯＋令.
歯 means “teeth”.
You can tell one’s age by his or her teeth.
So 齢 means “age” .

vocabulary: 読み上げる（よみあげる）：to read aloud
購読する（こうどくする）：to subscribe
売買する（ばいばいする）：to buy and sell
買収する（ばいしゅうする）：to acquire
聞く（きく）：to listen; to ask
聞こえる（きこえる）：to be able to hear
休む（やすむ）：to have a rest
夏休み（なつやすみ）：summer vacation
昼休み（ひるやすみ）：lunch break
休業（きゅうぎょう）：suspension of business
examples: 父ちちはいつも大声おおごえで話はなす。
My father always speaks in a very loud voice.
彼女かのじょは私わたしに役やくに立たつ話はなしをしてくれた。
She told me such stories as were useful.
本ほんを読よむ暇ひまがありません。
I don’t have time to read.
この本ほんは若わかい読者どくしゃにも理り解かいできる。
This book is within the capacity of young readers.
赤あかいネクタイを買かいました。
I bought a red tie.
彼かれの仕し事ごとは外国がいこくの買かい手てと交こう渉しょうすることだ。
His job is to negotiate with foreign buyers.
彼かれが無事ぶじだと聞きいて、私わたしは安心あんしんした。
I was relieved to hear that he was safe.
新聞しんぶんは生いき残のこれるだろうか。
Will newspapers be able to survive?
ちょっと休やすもうよ。
Let’s take a little rest.
来らい週しゅう二日ふつか間かんの休やすみを取とるつもりです。
I am going to take two days off next week.

origin_text: 計 = 言 + 十.
言 means “to say”. 十 means “ten”. You can say it out when you calculate something，and you need numbers to calculate things.
So 計 stands for “to calculate”.

meaning: In Japanese, 産 means “to give birth”.
origin_text: You can see a seedling here.
So 産 stands for “to give birth”.
The original meaning of 用 is “clock”.
If someone asked me the time, I need to use clock.
So 用 stands for “to use”.
You can see some water and a container.
You can remember 注 by
“I pour water into this container”.
So 注 stands for “to pour”.
The original meaning of 業 is “stands of musical instruments”.
You can remember it by “I am a musician, I need stands for musical instruments in order to work”.
So 業 stands for “work”.
You can see some rice.
If you want to cook, you need the material, and that is rice.
So 料 stands for “material”.
You can see a land, a hand and a foot.
You need the land to build the building.
You need to go to that land to see if it is okay for you to build the building.
And you need to make a drawing before you start to build the building.
So 建  stands for “to build”.
It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin.
However, I will think of a way to help you remember it.
You can see a tool.
Worker uses this tool to do his job.
So 工 stands for “worker”.
The original meaning of 員 is “circle”.
You can remember 員 by “members should stand in the circle”.
So 員 stands for “member”.
働=人 + 動
人 means “man”, 動 means “to move”.
If you want to work, you need to move.
So 働 stands for “to work”.
You can see three bowls. They are goods.
So 品  stands for “goods”.
You can see someone making clothes.
So 作 stands for “to make”.
You can see a man and an ax.
This man is an executioner.
He serves others by sentencing bad guys.
So 仕 stands for “to serve”.
You can see an emperor and a pillar. An emperor should learn plenty of things in order to become the pillar of his country. So 勉 stands for “to learn”.
You can see a horse and two people.
And you can remember 験 by “Two people are trying to ride this horse”.
So 験 stands for “to try”.
You can see a man and two mouths. You are explaining something to someone.
So 説 stands for “to explain”.
You can see a mouth, a tree and an ax.
You can remember 試 by “Someone says that he will try to cut the tree with this ax.”
So 試 stands for “to try”.
薬 = 艹 + 楽
艹 is a radical that means grass. 楽 means happy.
The medicine is made of grass and when you take medicine, you will feel happy.
So 薬 stands for “medicine”.
You can see a bird here.
The bird need to practice it again and again in order to learn how to fly.(the sun under the bird means that the bird often practices flying.)
So 習 stands for “to learn”.
You can see a man who is sitting here. You can remember it by “This man is thinking about the title of his article”. So 題 stands for “title”.
You can see a door and a mouth.
A man is asking questions at the door.
So 問 stands for “to ask”.
You can see a bowl here.
You can remember this kanji by “If you can answer this question, I will treat you”.
So 答 stands for  “to answer”.

meaning: In Japanese, 究 means “to make a profound study”.
origin_text: You can see a cave here.
You can remember this kanji by
“This man want to make a profound study of this cave”.
So 究 stands for “to make a profound study”.
You can see a stone.
You want to sharpen something using this stone.
So 研 stands for  “to sharpen”.
You can see a field and a stone.
You can remember this kanji by “I want to know the reason why this stone appears near from the field”.
So 理 stands for “reason”.
You can see an arrow and the mouth here.
The man said that he knew how to make arrows.
So 知 stands for “to know”.
It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin. However, I will think of a way to help you remember it.
You can see that a man is teaching his kid.
So 教 stands for “to teach”.
終 = 糸 + 冬。
糸 means “thread”.冬 means “winter”.
If you don’t have enough clothes, you will be over in the winter.
So 終  stands for “over”.
You can see the sun and the moon here.
In the early morning, the moon is still there.
So 朝 means “morning”.

meaning: In Japanese, 曜 means “day of the week”.
origin_text: It’s hard to remember kanji 曜 by its origin.
Below is a way to remember it.
You can see a heart here.
When you are in a hurry, the speed of your heart-beat will be faster.
急 stands for “to hurry”.
You can see a man here.
He is waiting for someone, and he is so bored that he begins to scratch his feet.
So 待 means “to wait”.
You can see someone measuring something using his hand here.
So 度 stands for “measure”.
You can see a man who feels very cold.
So 寒 stands for “cold”.
You can see a moon and a man.
A man is walking at night.
So 夜 stands for “night”.
It’s hard to remember kanji 昼 by its origin. Below is a way to remember it.
You can see the moon.
The moon will appear in the evening.
So 夕 stands for “evening”.
You can see some leaves.
Old leaves went away and new leaves come.
Just like people in this world.
So 世 stands for “world”.
You can see a man and a timber，the timber is used to tether the animals.
So it should be replaced often.
So 代 stands for “to replace”.
The original meaning of 冬 is “over”.
You can see that the rope is broken, so it means “it’s over”.
You can remember 冬 by
“The rope was broken in the winter.”
So 冬 stands for “winter”.
You can see the pest and fire.
You can remember 秋 by
“I burned the pests in order to protect the farm in the autumn.”
So 秋 stands for “autumn”.
The original meaning of 夏 is “China”.
You can remember 夏 by “I went to China this summer”
So 夏 stands for “summer”.
You can see the sun and seedling.
Everything on earth are coming back to life in spring.
So 春 stands for “spring”.
You can see a man who has no hair.
We didn’t have hair when we came to this world.
So it’s the original.
So 元 stands for “original”.
You can see that a vortex is spinning.
So 回 stands for “to spin”.
You can see that a man left his cave.
So 去 stands for “to leave”.
You can see a person and a cane.
You can remember it by “A person is eating the cane.”
So 者 stands for “person”.
You can see a knife.
You can remember it by
“I don’t know the way to use this knife”.
So 方 stands for “way”.
You can see someone is staring at you.
When someone is saying something true, he will be confident so that he will stare at you.
So 真 stands for “true”.
You can see a house and a candle.
The candle is the main tool for illumination long time ago.
So 主 stands for “main”.
You can see a seedling.
There is no way for the seedling to grow up if the ground is too hard.
So 不 stands for “no”.
You can see a house and some food.
The house is a hotel and you can eat some food in the hotel.
So 館 stands for “hotel”.
You can see a man and the footstep. The temple is built on top of the mountain. So you need the footstep to reach there.
So 院 stands for “temple”.
You can see a gate here.
So 門 stands for “gate”.
You can see a man, a mouth, a city and a tree.
There are many people and trees in the city, and people are talking to each other.
So 都 stands for “city”.
You can see a field and a soldier.
The soldiers are protecting the country in the border. And they need the field to eat.
So 界 stands for “border”.
It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin. However, I will think of a way to help you remember it.
You can see a field.
So 田 stands for “field”.
町 = 田 + 丁
田 is the field and 丁 is the border of the field.
In the town we use border of the field so that we won’t get confused.
So 町 stands for “town”.
You can see an emperor and a river.
The Chinese emperor is hang out near the river.
So 漢 stands for “China”.
You can see the sea and a woman.
The sea is the mother of the water.
So 海 stands for “sea”.
You can see some water and a goat here.
You can remember it by
“This goat lives near from the ocean.”
So 洋 stands for “ocean”.
You can see some water and a snake.
You can remember it by
“There is a snake in this pond”.
So  池 stands for “pond”.
You can see three trees here.
So 森 stands for “forest”.
You can see two trees.
So 林 stands for “woods”.
You can see a seedling, a man and a place.
Village is a place for people to live and farming.
So 村 stands for “village”.
You can see a window and an ax.
You can remember 所 by I live in a place where the window has been broken by someone using the ax.
So 所 stands for  “place”.
You can see a room.
So 室 stands for “room”.
You can see a stone and a snake, there are many stones and snakes on the ground long time ago.
So 地 stands for “ground”.
You can see a room.
So 屋 stands for “room”.
You can see a foot and a marketplace.
You use your feet to hang out at the marketplace. So 市 stands for “market”.
You can see an area to put something.
So 区 stands for “area”.
The original meaning of 場 is the place that used to hold on the sacrificial ceremony.
So you can see a knife here.
And now 場 is used to stand for “place”.
You can see some clay here.
So you can remember 堂 by
“This palace is made from clay”.
You can see a tall building.
So you can remember 京 by “There are plenty of tall buildings in the capital.”
You can see that someone lent the other one shells(money in ancient China).
So 貸 stands for “to lend”.
You can see a man, a mountain and the sun.
When you are climbing mountain under the sun, you will get thirsty soon, so you need to borrow the water from others.
So 借 stands for “to borrow”.
You can see a man carrying something heavy,
when you carry something heavy, you will lower your body.
So 低 stands for “low”.
You can see a tool, you can remember it by”I do something with this tool”.
So 以 stands for “with”.
You can see a bird here.
So 鳥 stands for “bird”.
You can see that a bird is walking because the wind is too strong.
So 風 stands for “wind”.
You can see that a bell is ringing now.
So 音 stands for “sound”.
You can see the field.
So it stands for “field”.
You can see something made by silver here, and it’s valuable in ancient China.
That’s why this man is looking at it.
So 銀 stands for “silver”.
You can see someone moving.
So 動 stands for “to move”.

meaning: In Japanese, 別 means “to break up with”.
origin_text: You can see a knife and the bone, when you break up with your girlfriend/boyfriend, it will be so painful that it feels like a knife is cutting your bone.
So it stands for “to break up with”.
運 = 辶 + 軍 辶 is a radical that means “to walk”，軍 means “army”. When the army walk，they need to carry lots of things.
So 運 stands for “to carry”.

meaning: In Japanese, 進 means “to move on”.
origin_text: You can see a bird and a foot. So you can remember it by “A man is moving on as fast as a bird”. So 進 stands for “to move on”.
You can see a wide road.
The wide road will make you easier to pass it.
So 通 stands for “to pass”.
You can see a kindling，in ancient China，kindling is very valuable，so if you send your kindling to others，it means you two are good friends.
So 送 stands for “to send”.
It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin.
However, I will  think of a way to help you remember it.
It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin. However, I will  think of a way to help you remember it.
You can see an army.
The original meaning of 旅 is the travel of army.
But now it just stands for “travel”.
便 = 人 + 更。
人 means “man”, 更 means “change”.
It means the man changes something inconvenient to make it convenient.
So 便 stands for “convenient”.
The original meaning of 首 is the head of animals.
So you can remember 首 by “The head of animal below is the neck”.
You can see a face here.
So 顔 stands for “face”.
You can see a head here.
So 頭 stands for “head”.
You can see a man who is doing some exercise.
You can remember it by “I am doing exercise.”
So 私 stands for “I”.
You can see a man lying on the bed because he is illness. So 病 stands for “disease”.
You can see a dog here.
So 犬 stands for “dog”.
The original meaning of 民 is “slave”.
In ancient China, the tyrant will make his people become his slaves.
You can see someone using the knife to stick the eyes of someone in order to make him obey.
So 民 stands for “people”.
You can see that a woman is crying because her kid died.
So 死 stands for “to die”.
It will be hard for you to remember this kanji by the origin because it changed too much. However, I will think of a way to help you remember it.
You can see a pig in the house, in ancient China, many houses have pigs in order to eat meat.
So 家 stands for “house”.
You can even hear something when you see the origin of 声, it seems very noisy, right?
So 声 stands for “voice”.
You can see a big man.
So 太 stands for “big” .
And you can see that it also have the meaning of “fat”, because you will be bigger when you get fat.
You can see a bowl full of rice, and someone trying to reach the bowl.
So 飯 stands for “rice”.
You can see someone trying to reach the vegetable. So kanji 菜 stands for “vegetable”.
You can see a plant here.
You use the plant to make tea.
So 茶 stands for “tea”.
You can see some meat.
So 肉 stands for “meat”.
You can see a mouth and a tree.
So you can remember 味 by
“I want to know the taste of this tree.”
The original meaning of kanji 正 is “to attack”. You can see a country and a foot (stands for soldiers) here.
So you can remember kanji 正 by
“It’s not correct to attack other countries”.
The original meaning of kanji 考 is “old”.
So you can see an old man here.
But now it means “to think”.
The old like to think things.
So kanji 考 stands for “to think”.
You can see a mouth and a heart here.
You need to  say it using your mouth, so that I can know what you are thinking in your heart(what you mean).
So 意 stands for “meaning”.
You can see a head and a heart here.
In ancient China, people think both head and heart are the organs to think.
So 思 stands for “to think”.
You can see a heart here.
So kanji 心 stands for “heart”.
好＝女＋子
女 means “woman”, 子 means “kid”.
When a woman has a kid, it’s a good thing.
Everyone likes good things.
So kanji 好 stands for “good” or “like”.
親＝亲＋見
亲＝立＋木
立 means “to stand”，木 means “tree”，見 means “to see”.
When you lost your way, your parents will worry about you, and they will stand at the tree so that they can see you.
So kanji 親 stands for “parent”.
You can see a flag and an arrow here, the flag stands for the race.
In order to protect your race, you need to use the bow and arrow to fight.
So kanji 族 stands for “race”.
You can see a tree and a rope here.
Your younger brother is very naughty, so in order to punish him, you use the rope to tie up him for a while.
So kanji 弟 stands for “younger brother”.
It’s hard to remember kanji 姉 by its origin.
Below is a way to help you remember it.
妹＝女＋未
女 means “woman”, 未 means “not”.
You are not seeing your younger sister as a woman who can be your girlfriend because she is your younger sister.
So kanji 妹 stands for “younger sister”.
You can see that a man is opening his mouth.
It means that your older brother often asks you to do something for him.
So 兄 stands for “older brother”.

meaning: In Japanese, 着 means “to put on; to arrive”.
origin_text: It’s hard to remember kanji 着 by its origin.
Below is a way to help you remember it.
着＝羊＋目
羊 means “sheep”，目 means “eye”.
So you can remember kanji 着 as “I put on something around the eyes of sheep”.
Below is the origin and development of the kanji 羊.
物＝牛＋勿
牛 means “cattle”, 勿 means “don’t”,
so you can remember kanji 物 by “things that the cattle don’t eat.”
It’s hard to remember kanji 台 by its origin.
Below is a way to help you remember it.
台＝ム＋口
口 looks like a stand, so you can remember it by a ム is on the stand, and it becomes 「台」.
You can see that two men are exchanging things.
The original meaning of kanji 質 is “mortgage”.
Only something whose quality is good can be used for mortgage, right?
So kanji 質 stands for “quality”.

meaning: In Japanese, 起 means “to get up”.
origin_text: You can see that someone is running here.
You need to get up in order to run, right?
So kanji 起 stands for “to get up”.
You can see that someone is running here.
So kanji 走 stands for “to run”.
You can see someone here, and he is trying to open the door.
So kanji 開 stands for “to open”.
You can see a bird on the tree.
Birds gathered on the tree.
So 集 stands for “to gather”.
You can see that a man is washing something,
so kanji 洗 stands for “to wash”.
You can see two footprints here.
They represent that someone is walking.
So kanji 歩 stands for “to walk”.
Note: Please note that Japanese kanji 歩 is  a little bit different from Chinese kanji 步.
The original meaning of kanji 止 is “foot”.
You need to stop your feet to stop walking, right?
So 止 stands for “stop” now.

meaning: In Japanese, 服 means “to obey; clothes”.
origin_text: You can see a big hand that try to grab this man, this man has to obey him.
So kanji 服 stands for “to obey”.
kanji 服 also stands for “clothes”, because your clothes should “obey” （fit)  your body so that you can put it on.
You can see someone trying to reach something, when you reach something, you have it.
So kanji 有 stands for “to have”.
You can see a hand and a foot here.
You can remember kanji 持 by
“I hold my foot with my hand”.
You can see a bow and an arrow here.
So 引 stands for “to pull”.
The original meaning of 始 is “pregnant”.
The new life will start when you have a baby, right?
So 始 stands for “to start”.

meaning: In Japanese, 帰 means “to go back”.
origin_text: The original meaning of 帰 is “woman got married”. When the woman got married, she will go back to home sometimes, right?
So 帰 stands for “to go back” now.
You can see a cover and a bowl, they fit each other.
So 合 stands for “to fit”.
使＝人＋吏 。
人 means “people”，吏 looks like a cane，and it means “official”.
Officials will have other people do something for them, right?
So 使 stands for “to use”.
住＝人＋主
人 means “human”，主 means “main”.
What is the main need for human? To live.
So 住 stands for “to live”.
The original meaning of 事 is “recorder”.
As a recorder, you need to record lots of things.
So 事 stands for “thing” now.
You can see someone cutting something.
So 切 stands for “to cut”.
You can see a man climbing the tree.
The original meaning of 乗 is “to climb”, and now it stands for “to ride”, because when you climb something, you will ride on it.
So 乗 stands for “to ride” now.
It’s hard to remember 画 by its origin because it has changed too much.
However, I will think of a way to help you remember it.
田 means “field”. You drew a painting of the field, and put it into a box, which is 画.
You can see the silk and a man.
In ancient, there is no paper, so people write on the silk.
So kanji 紙 stands for “paper”.
You can see someone singing a song.
So kanji 歌 stands for “song”.
You can see a bird here.
So you can remember kanji 写 by
“This bird wrote something on the wall”.

meaning: In Japanese, 映 means “to be reflected”.
origin_text: You can the sun and a man, something can be reflected when there is light,
so 映 stands for “to be reflected”.
You can see a knife and a woman.
So you can remember 色 by
“The woman has a colorful knife.”
The original meaning of 文 is “tattoo”, so you can remember it by
“The man with tattoo is good at writing articles.”
You can see a kid in the house, so you can remember it by “A kid is learning kanji in the house.”
You can see a map here.
So 図 means “map”.
You can see the cattle, hand and foot.
The cattle with man’s hands and feet is special.
So 特 stands for “special”.
You can see a 生 and a well.
生 means “seedling”，and below is a dye, you dye the seeding to blue, So 青 stands for “blue”.
You can see some feet and a street, it means if you want to go somewhere far from where you are, you need to walk a long distance.(the long clothes stands for the long road.)
So 遠 means “far”.
You can see a foot and an ax, when you are cutting trees, you need to be close to the tree, right?
So 近 stands for “close”.
It’s hard to remember kanji 軽 by its origin.
So I thought of a way to help you remember it.
軽＝車＋圣
車 means “car”, and 圣 means “holy”, holy’s car must be very light because it can fly.
So 軽 stands for “light”.
You can see the fire.
The fire is red.
So 赤 stands for “red”.
You can see a strong man and a big bag, the bag must be very heavy, so 重 stands for “heavy”.
The original meaning of 自 is “nose”, but now it stands for “myself”.
Because when you want to say “it’s me.”, you often point to your nose.
examples: 彼は試合に勝つ自信がある。
He is sure of winning the game.
大丈夫、君なら出来る！自分を信じて！
It’ll be fine, you can do it! Trust yourself!
自然な状態の髪の毛には、油分が含まれています。
There is oil in hair in its natural state.
しかし、主人公は自らの誤りに気づいている。
However the protagonist is aware of his own mistakes.
結局は誰でも自分で学ぶしかない。
Everyone must learn on their own in the end.
絶望した彼は自殺を図った。
Despair drove him to attempt suicide.
あいつ、自分が音痴だってこと知らないんだよ。
He doesn’t realize that he’s tone deaf.

origin_text: You can see an arrow, an arrow is used as a standard thing.
If something is shorter than an arrow, then we can say this thing is short.
So 短 stands for “short”.
examples: 誰にでも長所と短所がある。
Everyone has both strong and weak points.
要するに人生は短い。
In a word, life is short.
彼女は短気だ。
She has a hot temper.
彼女は短いスカートが好きだ。
She likes short skirts.
彼女は短編小説の作家です。
She is a short story writer.
彼らは労働時間の短縮を要求している。
They are demanding shorter working hours.
彼は手短に答えた。
He answered in brief.
短期間で英語を習得することはできない。
You can not master English in a short time.

origin_text: You can see a kind of musical instrument.
So 楽 stands for “music”.
And you feel happy when you are listening to music, so 楽 means “happy” too.
examples: 彼は音楽会が終わるまでには到着しなかった。
He didn’t arrive until the concert was over.
模型飛行機を作るのは楽しい。
Making a model plane is interesting.
私はうるさい音楽は好きではない。たとえばロックのような。
I don’t like noisy music, such as rock.
あなたの仕事は楽じゃないわよ。
I’m afraid the job I’ve got for you won’t be easy.
私の大好きな音楽はポップミュージックだ。
My favorite music is pop music.
来週お会いするのを楽しみにしています。
I’m looking forward to seeing you next week.

origin_text: 暗＝日＋音。
日 means “sun”，and 音 stands for “closed door” here, when you close the door and there is no light, the house will be dark. So 暗 means “dark”.
examples: 彼女は暗いところをとても怖がる。
She is very afraid of the dark.
外が暗くなってきた。
It’s getting darker outside now.
来週までにその詩を暗記しなさい。
Memorize the poem by next week.
暗闇の中で目が見えますか。
Can you see in the darkness?
僕の目の前が、真っ暗になった。
Everything went black.
部屋の中は暗くて寒かった。
It was dark and cold in the room.

origin_text: 暑＝日＋者
日 means “sun”，and the original meaning of 者 is “to boil”，The weather is hot so that you can boil something under the sun.
So 暑 stands for “hot”.
examples: 早く帰った方がいい、暑いから。
It’s hot, so you’d better head back quickly.
彼女は暑さには弱いんです。
She is sensitive to the heat.
今日はとても暑い。
It is very hot today.
毎日こんなに暑いのですか。
Is it this hot every day?
彼は暑さのために食欲がなかった。
He had no appetite because of the heat.
窓を開けてくれ。ここは暑くてたまらない。
Open the window. It’s baking hot in here.

origin_text: It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin. However, I will think of a way to help you remember this kanji easier.
悪＝亜＋心，亜 looks like a dumbbell，心 means “heart”，when a man’s heart is as heavy as a dumbbell, it will be not good. So it stands for “bad”.
examples: 予想した以上に悪い天候だ。
This bad weather is more than I bargained for.
彼は最悪の事態に備えておく必要がある。
It is necessary that he should prepare for the worst.
彼は最悪の事態を覚悟した。
He prepared for the worst.
良い事、悪い事を区別するのは簡単だ。
It is easy to distinguish good from evil.
だってこの世には悪者と偽善者しかいないのよ。
You see in this world there are only scoundrels and hypocrites.
悪者にされたくない。
I don’t want to be made a bad guy.

origin_text: 強＝弘＋虫
弘 means “big”，and 虫 means “insect”.
Big insect is strong，so 強 stands for “strong”.
examples: 彼は普通の人より遥かに力が強い。
His strength is much greater than that of an ordinary man.
遊びが増えれば勉強する時間が減ることになるだろう。
More play will mean less time to study.
コンクリートは中に鋼鉄の棒を入れる事で補強される。
Concrete can be reinforced by putting steel bars inside it.
彼は我々にそのルールを守るように強く命じた。
He urged us to obey the rule.
彼らは僕たちと同じくらい強い。
They are as strong as us.
普段は友人が息子の勉強を見てくれます。
My friend usually helps my son with his studies.
素朴な疑問なんだけど、トラとライオンはどっちが強いの？
This may be a silly question, but which is stronger – a tiger or a lion?
その板は重さに堪えるに十分な強度がある。
The board is strong enough to bear the weight.

origin_text: You can see two bows, and the bowstring is loose.
Man who uses it will be weaker than others.
So 弱 stands for “weak”.
examples: 僕の弱点を見つけさせないぞ。
You won’t find my weak point.
彼女は生まれつき弱い。
She is weak by nature.
彼女は暑さには弱いんです。
She is sensitive to the heat.
彼は病弱なので心配だ。
I am concerned about his poor health.
彼は弱者に深い思いやりがある。
He has a deep feeling for the weak.
彼は体の弱い子供だった。
He was a weak and delicate child.
彼は視力が弱い。
He has poor eyesight.
彼の英語の知識は貧弱である。
His knowledge of English is poor.

origin_text: It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin. However, I will think of a way to help you remember this kanji.
広=广＋ム，广 is a house, and 無（む、ム）means “nothing”, there is nothing in the house, the house must be wide, so 広 stands for “wide”.
examples: 私たちは広い範囲に渡る話題について話し合った。
We discussed a wide range of topics.
彼はくたくたの背広を着ていた。
He was wearing a threadbare suit.
まあ、広義的には間違っていませんね。
Well, broadly speaking that’s right.
旅行は人の視野を広める。
Travel broadens one’s horizons.
妙な噂が広がっている。
Queer rumors are in the air.
父は家族の居間を広くした。
Father made our living room more spacious.
彼女は広い家に住んでいます。
She lives in a large house.
彼女はテーブルの上にクロスを広げた。
She spread a cloth over the table.

origin_text: 同＝凡＋口.
It means that everyone say the same thing.
So 同 stands for “same”.
examples: これはまさに私が失くした同じカメラです。
This is exactly the same camera that I have lost.
病院に運び込まれたとき、彼は死んだも同然だった。
He was all but dead when taken to the hospital.
実力が伯仲したチーム同士の対戦なので面白い試合になりそうだ。
Both teams are well matched. The game will be an interesting one.
彼らは僕たちと同じくらい強い。
They are as strong as us.
小説だって絵と同様に練習が必要なんだから。
Because novels, just like paintings, need you to practice.
母ちゃんも同じこと言ってたな。だからどうしたってんだよ。俺には関係ない。
Mum said the same thing. But, so what? It’s got nothing to do with me.
彼らは隣同士です。
They are next door neighbors.
生まれると同時に死は始まる。
As soon as man is born, he begins to die.

reading: Note: There is some difference between Chinese kanji and Japanese kanji, you should use Japanese kanji.
origin_text: You can see a bone here.
So 骨 means “bone”.

You need to stop the horse when you want to get down from it.

Its fragrance smells good.
So 香 means “fragrance”.
額=客+頁.
客 means “guest”.(So you can see someone who is coming into a cave).
頁 looks like a person. He is your guest.
You need to touch his forehead to check that is he ill.
So 額 means “forehead”.
You can see someone ordering someone.
And the other man received it.
So 領 means “to receive”.
You can see a jade here.
He wants to keep the jade.
So 預 means “to keep”.
You can see the leather here.
So 革 means “leather”.

The earth seems to shake when the lighting came.
So 震 means “to shake”.
You can see the rain here.
It won’t influence your life too much.
So 零 means “zero”.
You can see a bird here.
So you can remember this kanji by “I hired someone to feed my bird.”
You can see one bird here.
So 隻 means “one”.
You can see a monkey here.
You can remember this kanji by “There is a monkey in the corner.”
So 隅 means “corner”.
You can see a mountain here.
It is used to prevent the attack from other countries.
You can see an ax.
The ax is very sharp.
So 鋭 means “sharp”.
銅=金+同.
金 means “gold”, 同 means “the same”.
So you can remember this kanji by “This copper is the same as gold.”

reading: Note: Below is the origin and development of kanji 金.
origin_text: It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin.
However, you can remember this kanji this way.
鉱=金+広, 金 means “gold”, it stands for metal. And 広 means “wide”.
The ore is widespread.
So 鉱 means “ore”.
You can see a blunt ax.
So 鈍 means “blunt”.
You can see a needle here.
So 針 means “needle”.
You can see the plant here.
It represents the station.
So 郵 means “mail”.
You can see 交 here.
It means “to cross”.
So if you cross the suburb, you will be in another country.
So 郊 means “suburb”.
You can see the house and the boat.
They are something that people built.
So 造 means “to build”.
You can see a man who is upside down.
So 逆 means “upside down”.
You can see a plant here.
This man is stating something about the plant.
So 述 means “to state”.
You can see a knife here.
The food is so spicy that it seems a knife are stabbing your heart.
So 辛 means “spicy”.
You can see the car here.
You need a car when you transport something.
So 輸 means “transport”.
You can see a car and a man who is yawning.
The seat must be very soft.
So 軟 means “soft”.
You can see a car and a tree.
It means that every house has a car and a tree.
So 軒 is “counter for houses”.
You can see the foot and the musical instruments.
You need music to dance.
So 踊 means “to dance”.

reading: Note: There is some difference between Chinese kanji and Japanese kanji, you should use Japanese kanji，which has a 足 on the left.
origin_text: You can see a foot here.
You left the trace by your feet.
So 跡 means “trace”.
You can see a foot and mouth here.
It means that if you want to exceed someone, you need to exceed him/her both in the body part and the speaking skill.
So 超 means “to exceed”.
You can see the shell and some food.
You can remember this kanji by “He gave you some money and some food.”
So 贈 means “to give”.
You can see a man surrendered and a fist.
You are smart when you surrender if you think you can’t win, and fight when you think you can win.
So 賢 means “smart”.
You can see the door open and the shell.
It means that you need to be open when you are in a trade.
So 貿 means “trade”.
You can see the shell here.
Shell is money.
You sell something for money.
So 販 means “to sell”.

reading: Note: There is some difference between Chinese kanji and Japanese kanji, you should use Japanese kanji. （Which has a 曲 above.）
origin_text: You can see many fruits here.
This family must be very rich.
So 豊 means “rich”.
You can see some fish here.
You can remember this kanji by “This is a lecture about the fish.”
So 講 means “lecture”.
You can see two mouths here.
It means that many people are talking about their opinions.
So 諸 means “various”.

reading: Note: Below is the origin and development of kanji 志.
origin_text: 誌 = 言 + 志.
言 means “to say”.
You can remember this kanji by “志”, which means “will”.(So you can see a heart here.) In a magazine, you talk about your will.
So 誌 means “magazine”.
You can see the ax and a box.
You can remember this kanji by “You need to use the box to pack the ax.”
So 詰 means “to pack”.

reading: Note:台詞、捨て台詞、名台詞 are often written as セリフ、捨てゼリフ and 名ゼリフ.This is because they don’t follow the reading of kanji. They are exceptions.
origin_text: You can see someone talking.
So 詞 means “word”.
You can see a man providing something.
So 設 means “to provide”.

reading: Note: Below is the origin and development of kanji 角.
origin_text: It’s hard to remember this kanji by its origin because it changed too much. However, you can remember this kanji by kanji 角 and 虫. 触 = 角 + 虫. 角 means “horn”, and 虫 means “bug”. So you can remember this kanji by “Don’t touch the horn, there are bugs on it!”

reading: Note: Below is the origin and development of kanji 復.

So you can remember this kanji by “He made up by giving you some coats and fields”.
